scenes.label: *start
texts: It was a private room located within the Gai Institution.
One of the walls was made of glass, a large window to an expanse of high-rise buildings along the coast.
The room belonged to the head researcher, Asuma Soga. He wasn't present right now, however.
Major Graham Kingly was there instead, accompanied by six armed soldiers. They'd burst into the room and secured it.
Doing as Graham ordered, Alpha Team started using heavy-looking sensors on the many stuffed animals in the room's corner.
They were searching for wiretaps and the like.
Narashino, relay the current location of Ouranos.
Traveling north on Route 5. Arriving at Bijogi Junction in seven minutes.
Target B is clean. No metal detected.
Three of the six soldiers were using detectors to scan the stuffed animals.
After being handed the scanned animals, the others took out their knives, and...
Scanning alone couldn't guarantee that there were no wiretaps.
Just to be safe, they pulled out the cotton stuffing and thoroughly checked inside each one.
There were fewer than ten in total.
Some were far larger than others though, so it would take time to remove all the cotton and examine them.
Asuma Soga and Ewan Okuda had taken a car to go to a meeting half an hour ago.
Graham had taken this opportunity to commence this operation.
The objective was to investigate the stuffed animals that Ewan regularly bought for Asuma.
Graham suspected that they had wiretaps inside.
Ewan Okuda was an engineer belonging to a national research company. He'd been part of Project GAIA since before its development was frozen.
He'd simply been another member of the project back then, but now, he was someone you could call Asuma's right-hand man.
Graham believed that this was the result of both his skill as an engineer as well as his ability to keep Asuma satisfied.
Asuma used Ewan as his own attendant, keeping him close by at all times.
After the AOAB Director-General was exposed as a spy one year ago, security for both GAIA and Asuma had greatly increased.
Ewan was the one who'd shot the spy that day.
Graham always felt something was off about Ewan. There was no particular reason, but if he had to give one, it'd be his soldier's intuition.
He'd looked into Ewan's past, just in case, but found nothing incriminating. However deep he dug, there was no indication the man was shady.
Graham couldn't shake that strange feeling though, even now.
In his mind, it was still possible that Ewan Okuda was an industry spy, and Graham had planned this operation to confirm it.
As planned, Ouranos has left the Wako Interchange.
Today, Asuma had gone to a meeting at Riken.
He wouldn't be back for at least two hours.
Keep track of them. Don't lose sight of Ouranos.
The soldier pointed at the bear Ewan had bought most recently.
Graham took the bear by the head...
...and tore it open with his own bare hands.
He forced his hand inside and examined it without care or restraint.
They retrieved the torn stuffed animals and began carefully replacing them with exact substitutes they'd prepared.
This was to keep anyone from realizing the operation had taken place at all.
All right, let's withdraw. Leave no evidence.
As they prepared to leave, the stuffed animal remains in hand...
...the door suddenly opened, and the soldiers ran right into the people on the other side.
An army man doing a janitor's job? How embarassing.
It was Asuma Soga—the owner of the room—and Ewan Okuda.
Graham had to keep himself from nodding.
The operations room in Camp Narashino was tracking Asuma and Ewan.
According to Narashino, the pair were about to arrive at Riken, in Saitama.
Your people are pretty good at tracking. Tracking an empty car, that is.
It took an extremely skilled hacker to fool the army's systems.
That didn't surprise Graham, though. He knew Asuma was capable of such a feat.
When did you figure out our plan?
Hmph. Are you really that stupid?
Do you still think you can hide things from me?
You've been here for about a year now. Isn't it about time you got the picture?
And you think that Ewan's a spy. Well, I hope you've learned something here.
This operation was necessary to ensure maximum security. I apologize for not informing you about it.
Asuma had already stopped listening to Graham. Instead, he sat down and began doing something on his cube-shaped input device.
Graham told his soldiers to leave, then did the same himself.
It wasn't the outside, but an artificial visual.
What it actually showed was the finest trait of the Earth Simulator, GAIA—its spherical monitor.
Yeah. No one can fool me, or hide anything from me...
So...why? Why didn't the thing with the woman turn out as it was simulated?
The last person here besides Asuma—Ewan—called out to him, triggering an irritated scowl.
Who gave you permission to stay here? Get out.
The government operation to capture the girl has already ended. Further involvement is forbidden.
You really think I'll just do as they tell me?
You weren't even interested at first.
But it didn't go as simulated, and I can't just ignore that.
My GAIA is supposed to be perfect. This matter can't be overlooked.
